question: What are the symptoms, causes, and treatment of Chlamydia? (version 1)
symptoms: Often asymptomatic; possible symptoms include painful urination, abnormal genital discharge, pelvic pain (in women), testicular pain (in men).
causes: Bacterial infection (Chlamydia trachomatis), transmitted through unprotected vaginal, anal, or oral sex.
treatment: Antibiotics (azithromycin or doxycycline), partner treatment, follow-up testing.
layman_explanation: Chlamydia is a common STD that often shows no symptoms but can cause pain and discharge. It’s easily cured with antibiotics.

question: What are the symptoms, causes, and treatment of Gonorrhea? (version 1)
symptoms: Painful urination, thick yellow/green discharge, pelvic pain (women), swollen testicles (men), sometimes asymptomatic.
causes: Bacterial infection (Neisseria gonorrhoeae), spread through unprotected sex (vaginal, anal, oral).
layman_explanation: Gonorrhea is a bacterial STD that can cause painful peeing and discharge. It’s treated with antibiotics, but some strains are becoming resistant.

question: What are the symptoms, causes, and treatment of Syphilis? (version 1)
symptoms: Stages: 1) Painless sores (chancre), 2) Rash, fever, swollen glands; 3) Severe organ damage (if untreated).
causes: Bacterial infection (Treponema pallidum), spread via direct contact with sores during sex or from mother to baby.
treatment: Penicillin (effective in all stages), alternative antibiotics for allergies.
layman_explanation: Syphilis starts with painless sores but can lead to serious health problems if untreated. It’s curable with penicillin shots.

question: What are the symptoms, causes, and treatment of HPV? (version 1)
symptoms: Often none; some strains cause genital warts (bumps), others lead to cancers (cervical, throat).
causes: Viral infection (HPV types 6/11 cause warts; 16/18 cause cancer), spread via skin-to-skin sexual contact.
treatment: No cure; vaccines (Gardasil) prevent high-risk strains; warts treated with creams/surgery.
layman_explanation: HPV is a very common virus. Some types cause warts, others can lead to cancer. Vaccines can prevent the most dangerous kinds.

question: What are the symptoms, causes, and treatment of Herpes? (version 1)
symptoms: Painful blisters/sores on genitals/mouth, itching, flu-like symptoms during outbreaks; can be asymptomatic.
causes: HSV-1 (oral/genital) or HSV-2 (mostly genital), spread via skin-to-skin contact, even without sores.
layman_explanation: Herpes causes recurring sores, but many people have no symptoms. Medicine can help manage outbreaks.

question: What are the symptoms, causes, and treatment of HIV/AIDS? (version 1)
symptoms: Early: Flu-like illness; Late (AIDS): Weight loss, infections, cancers due to weakened immune system.
causes: Virus (HIV) transmitted via blood, semen, vaginal fluids, breast milk (unprotected sex, needles, childbirth).
treatment: Antiretroviral therapy (ART) to control virus; no cure but manageable with medication.
layman_explanation: HIV attacks the immune system. Without treatment, it can lead to AIDS, but daily meds help people live long, healthy lives.

question: What are the symptoms, causes, and treatment of Trichomoniasis? (version 1)
symptoms: Itching, burning, frothy discharge (often green/yellow), discomfort during sex/urination; sometimes asymptomatic.
causes: Parasite (Trichomonas vaginalis), spread via unprotected sex.
treatment: Antibiotics (metronidazole or tinidazole), partner treatment required.
layman_explanation: Trichomoniasis is an STD caused by a parasite, leading to itching and discharge. It’s easily treated with antibiotics.

question: What are the symptoms, causes, and treatment of Hepatitis B? (version 1)
symptoms: Fatigue, jaundice (yellow skin/eyes), dark urine, abdominal pain; can be chronic (liver damage/cancer).
causes: Virus (HBV) spread via blood, semen (sex, needles, childbirth).
treatment: Vaccine prevents it; chronic cases managed with antivirals (tenofovir).
layman_explanation: Hepatitis B affects the liver and can become chronic. A vaccine prevents it, and meds help manage chronic infections.

question: What are the physiological and psychological benefits? (version 1)
advantages: Stress relief (endorphins), improved sleep, stronger pelvic muscles, boosted immunity, lower blood pressure.
disadvantages: Risk of STDs/unplanned pregnancy if unprotected; emotional consequences (e.g., regret, attachment issues).
layman_explanation: Sex can improve mood and health, but safety and consent are key.

question: What are the dangers of skipping protection? (version 1)
risks: STD transmission (HIV, Syphilis, etc.), unplanned pregnancy, emotional distress.
prevention: Condoms, regular STD testing, mutual monogamy, PrEP (for HIV).
layman_explanation: Unprotected sex can lead to lifelong infections or unexpected parenthood. Always use protection.

question: How effective are condoms in preventing STDs and pregnancy? (version 1)
protection: ~98% effective against STDs/HIV when used correctly; also prevents pregnancy (~85–98%).
advantages: Cheap, widely available, no hormonal side effects, protects against most STDs.
disadvantages: Can break/slip; latex allergies; reduced sensation for some users.
layman_explanation: Condoms are the best dual-protection method against both STDs and pregnancy.

question: Who should use PrEP for HIV prevention? (version 1)
protection: ~99% effective against HIV if taken daily; does not protect against other STDs.
advantages: Ideal for high-risk groups (e.g., partners of HIV+ individuals, sex workers).
disadvantages: Requires prescription; side effects (nausea, kidney monitoring); no STD protection.
layman_explanation: PrEP is a daily pill for HIV-negative people to avoid infection. Still need condoms for other STDs.

question: Which STDs can be prevented by vaccines? (version 1)
protection: HPV vaccine (Gardasil 9) prevents 90% of cancer-causing strains; Hepatitis B vaccine is 95% effective.
disadvantages: Requires multiple doses; not all strains covered (HPV).
layman_explanation: Vaccines can stop HPV (linked to cancer) and Hepatitis B (liver damage) before exposure.
